newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: South Korean won ends down on import deals.
newsitem.headline: South Korean won ends down on import deals.

text.p: The South Korean won ended Monday's trading lower after drifting against the U.S. unit in the afternoon session, pressured by import settlements and speculative dollar buying, dealers said.
The U.S. unit's rise is expected to continue, fueled by South Korea's huge trade deficit.
The won ended at 868.60 against an opening high of 866.50. It fell to a low of 868.80 early in the day.
"Aside from intervention by the central bank, we believe there are no strong factors to bolster the won from falling still further," a local trader said.
"Contrary to most expectations, the central bank did not intervene when the won had reached 868, allowing an additional 0.60 fall (in the won) by market closing," said a local dealer.
Traders predicted the dollar/won would range between 868-870.
Tuesday's base mid-rate is expected to be pegged at 867.80, unchanged from Monday.
